content: >http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-03-19-voa32.cfm President Sarkozy is developing a backlash to his nouvelle France. Over a million workers hit the streets yesterday to protest his new economic policy. This less than a week after the garcon merveilleux declared that France was 're-enlisting' in NATO. Ostensibly a protest against the economy, it's hard to see how the workers are going to square restraint for them with the cost of a burgeoning military operation for the sake of OTAN in Afghanistan. Mr Sarkozy my have blown some 'gloire et honneur' past the pols but he won't get it past the workers.
reply: >http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-03-19-voa32.cfm President Sarkozy is developing a backlash to his nouvelle France. Over a million workers hit the streets yesterday to protest his new economic policy. This less than a week after the garcon merveilleux declared that France was 're-enlisting' in NATO. Ostensibly a protest against the economy, it's hard to see how the workers are going to square restraint for them with the cost of a burgeoning military operation for the sake of OTAN in Afghanistan. Mr Sarkozy my have blown some 'gloire et honneur' past the pols but he won't get it past the workers.
title: Les Francais Hit La Rue

content: The French people don't fear the government. American's do. That's why France is a great country, with a fantastic world-class universal health care system, worker rights like in no other country, they don't get bogged down in meaningless wars, and it's citizens are world travelers. If I could speak the language better, because it's alot like America in that, their people only speak their own language and rarely other languages, I'd spend more time there "I believe that banking institutions are more dangerous to our liberties than standing armies." - T. Jefferson
